article_title: Letter: Brad Schneider trying to hide harmful health care vote
article_text:
Dear Editor:

As a former Illinois state representative and the former director of the Illinois Department of Healthcare and Family Services, I am deeply disappointed in Brad Schneider and his attempted cover-up of an obviously harmful vote while he was in Congress. There are a number of reasons I am supporting Nancy Rotering for Congress and this is the one of the most important.

His support for specific legislation (HR 2575) would have deprived health care benefits to those who need it most. This legislation, supported by Schneider, would have changed the definition of "full-time employee" under the Affordable Care Act. Currently, employers must provide health care for any employee who works an average of at least 30 hours a week. HR 2575 would have changed the law so employers would be required only to offer health care to employees who work a minimum of 40 hours.

This bill would have undermined Obamacare by reducing the number of employees receiving health insurance coverage. That is why the Obama administration adamantly was against the legislation. All Republicans and only 18 Democrats voted for it (only Schneider and Daniel Lipinski in Illinois).

I heard Schneider try to downplay this serious error in judgment by saying on WTTW Channel 11 recently that this was just a change in "category definition" – which he had to know was false. In fact, this change in "category definition" would have forced 1 million people to lose their health insurance coverage and increase the number of uninsured. The independent, nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office conducted that analysis.

As the director of the Illinois Department of Healthcare and Family Services during the critical period when the Affordable Care Act was being implemented, I saw the immediate benefits in terms of improved lives and cost savings. I remain today totally committed to the continued expansion of and access to health care. That's why I am supporting Nancy Rotering, who has the professional background and values I believe in and the strength to pursue them effectively. I hope you will too.

Julie Hamos

Evanston
